Update - September 1, 2020: The nationwide waiver has been extended through December 31. Please see nkcschools.org/meals for the latest information.

As students return to the classroom and virtual studies on Tuesday, September 8, NKC Schools has determined that it is the right time to shift to Phase 1 of our Return to School Plan for Food & Nutrition Services.

The nationwide waiver that allowed schools to feed all students for free has expired. Beginning Sep. 8, families will be encouraged to pay for meals in advance of pick-up. Students who qualify for free or reduced price meals will continue to receive free breakfast and lunch. The following sites have been designated as grab & go locations every Monday through Friday from 10 a.m. through 1 p.m. More information is available at nkcschools.org/meals.

Yesterday, the NKC Schools Board of Education approved new academic calendars for the 2020-2021 school year.

The first day of school for all students, whether attending face-to-face or through a virtual option, will be Tuesday, September 8. This includes our learners returning to continue their year at Crestview and Winnwood. We will discontinue the Thursday Early Release schedule for the 2020-2021 school year, instead following the traditional school day schedule. October 26 and February 12, originally designated as professional development days for our staff, will become regular student attendance days. February 15, Presidents Day, will also become a student attendance day. Detailed versions of all updated academic calendars are also available at nkcschools.org/calendar.

What does “zero tax increase” really mean? How can you raise $155 million without raising taxes?

Thanks to the fiscal responsibility of North Kansas City Schools Board of Education, the district has paid off a large portion of debt incurred from past construction projects. Effective management of funds has allowed us to seek approval of an additional $155 million to meet current needs. The levy of $1.29 would simply remain in place to ensure funding for the students of North Kansas City Schools. Patrons would not see an increase in taxes. It’s similar to refinancing your home mortgage in order to construct an addition while keeping payments the same.

Visit www.nkcschools.org/bond2020 for complete details and remember to vote June 2. #NKCBond2020

We value the opportunity to engage with our community on social media. Comments are always encouraged, but we want to ensure that we provide a safe digital environment for all. Our social media pages are monitored during regular business hours, and all exchanges should be informative, respectful of diverse viewpoints and lawful. Personal attacks, profanity, illegal content and spam are not permitted and may be deleted. If you have a reasonable question, we do our best to answer. Comments that do not adhere to our guidelines will not receive a response.

If you have additional questions, visit our district website and click on “Let’s Talk” or call the district office at 816-321-5000. Please also take a moment to review our social media guidelines: https://www.nkcschools.org/cms/lib/MO49000025/Centricity/Domain/6184/PARENT-COMMUNITY_Social_Media_Guidelines_2019.pdf
Thank you for your help in maintaining a safe online community.

Pending the outcome of the April 7 zero-tax increase bond measure, the high school will receive its own home stadium complex, new weight room, modern south-facing entryway for students, an additional elevator, and new and renovated restrooms.
